intro: Gilia scopulorum var. typica, commonly known as the desert gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Plantaginaceae family and is characterized by its slender, upright stems and clusters of showy, pink to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions. Its flowering period occurs in the spring and early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The species is often found in desert scrub and chaparral habitats, contributing to the ecological diversity of these regions.
